posts.author: Jidokwon
posts.content: Good day!  My searching through the builds here is still quite limited, but it's been extremely rare that I've found any builds that make use of any of the social skills.  I can certainly understand why most of the builds seem to focus almost entirely on min/max for combat purposes.  My questions here relate more to building well rounded characters that might do reasonably well, too, in dialogue intensive PWs and/or campaigns.  For such occasions, are these kinds of skills just about mandatory to keep as high as possible?  Or, in general, are there certain points that I might take them to then "slack" off to focus more on the combative skills?  Again, my searching and reading here has been very limited, so far, but I recall seeing that many of the thief and bard type skills are rarely required to keep up beyond certain points.  For *most* dialogue intensive occasions, can social skills, too, be kept reasonably low?

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
It is an interesting question you pose here, Jidokwon.
It is for the most part true that the priority of most builds here is to handle combat well.
Some builds also have a focus on thieving skills and support actions.

What makes a "good enough" build, depends to a large degree on what you will be up against in the module or PW where you play, and also on what items will be available. When we post builds here, and when we give advice, we aim at being able to handle rather tough environments.

Social skills are a bit different from other skills in the respect that they have no standard target values. Module designers decide what DC they give the skill checks, and some even have different ways of checking the skills other than the regular d20 roll. So what is good enough, really depends on where you play.
You can play and test, or you can open the module in the toolset and study closer the different options that appear in dialogues if you want to be sure.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Any build with 14 INT & lots of Rogue levels will have an abundance of skill points. You could experiment with that but there are very few modules where the social skills will have a significant impact on the gameplay because of their single-player nature. Usually, modules have a static DC for their targets such as the diplomacy check at the end of HotU. Some modules might require a significant investment in certain skills & their targets can be fairly high such as Spot & Search in Sands of Fate series. Additionally, there is one module that I know of that uses social skills & their targets grow with your level, that is Swordflight. I don't remember what happens in Aielund Saga, perhaps Mick or Stag are better to answer this.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I know you certainly can make use of social skills in Aielund in assorted amounts and in various occasions throughout the campaign. They can alter the way certain (sometimes significant) conflicts may be resolved without bloodshed - though not the final results. You won't lose xp either, though some of the treasure rewards and loot will obviously be different (but still scaled with level).

@Empyre65  certainly ran his Persuasive Archer (a half-elf Rogue/ Bard/ AA - though I might be wrong about Bard) through the campaign successfully. He's not published it in the Level 40 forum, but it can certainly be found in the Aielund and another one or two other threads as well, adapted for different environments.
